channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Trump’s Backers in Congress, ‘Devil Terms’ Help Rally Voters
item.description: In vilifying tweets and speeches, G.O.P. lawmakers who contested the election have far outpaced other Republicans and Democrats in fueling polarization.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Steve Eder
item.category: This Will Not Pass: Trump, Biden, and the Battle for America's Future (Book)
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Xi Jinping Now Holds Near-Absolute Power in China, Creating Risks
item.description: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Chang Che
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, left, with new members of the Politburo Standing Committee at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: China Hangs on Xi’s Every Word. His Silence Also Speaks Volumes.
item.description: At the important Communist Party congress this week, the Chinese leader didn’t mention two long-repeated maxims. To many, it’s a warning of the turbulent times ahead.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Li Xueren/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, is expected to secure a precedent-defying third term at the end of the Communist Party congress.

item.title: Hu Jintao Was Escorted Out of China’s Congress, Raising Questions
item.description: A health scare? A brazen political gesture? Whatever else it was, the episode was awkward.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: The unexpected departure of a former leader, Hu Jintao, standing, who apparently paused to speak to Mr. Xi before being escorted out, caused a brief stir during in proceedings that are usually tightly choreographed.

item.title: ‘We Heard It, We Saw It, Then We Opened Fire’
item.description: With an intense, hastily assembled effort, the Ukrainian military is pioneering successful techniques in the difficult art of anti-drone warfare.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Vadim Sarakhan/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers in Kyiv, Ukraine, trying to shoot down a drone during an attack on Oct. 17. The drone was believed to be an Iranian-made Shahed-136, purchased by Russia in August.

item.title: Russian Superyachts in Turkey Raise Concerns in Washington
item.description: Turkey’s welcoming ports are symptoms of a much larger problem: evasion of U.S. sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Elif Ince, Michael Forsythe and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Elif Ince for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solaris, a superyacht linked to the Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, in the Yalıkavak Bay in Bodrum, Turkey, in August.

item.title: How Political Primaries Drive Britain’s Dysfunction
item.description: In the United States, too, the rise of inside-party primaries has empowered candidates at the extremes, and the result is likely to be a greater disconnect with the public.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: 10 Downing Street in London, where Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned this week. Ms. Truss was only the fourth British leader to win the job through a party primary.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Pulls Ahead With Votes in UK Prime Minister Race
item.description: Conservative Party lawmakers have so far put more weight behind Rishi Sunak to be their next leader, but Boris Johnson is still in the fight to reclaim Downing Street.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Nigel Roddis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak in July at a Conservative Party event in Leeds, England.

item.title: Ralph Fiennes Is Playing Robert Moses in ‘Straight Line Crazy’
item.description: He’s playing New York’s own Caesar, Robert Moses, in a stage production at the Shed.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

item.title: A ‘Tripledemic’? Flu and Other Infections Return as Covid Cases Rise
item.description: Flu cases are higher than usual for this time of year and are expected to soar in the coming weeks. A third virus, R.S.V., is straining pediatric hospitals in some states.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young girl receiving a Covid test at Esperanza Health Center in Chicago in September.

item.title: Blunder in Affirmative Action Case May Cost Harvard $15 Million
item.description: A missed insurance notice opened a window onto the cost of litigating challenges to race-conscious admissions programs to be heard this month by the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments in the affirmative action case involving Harvard on Oct. 31.

item.title: For Eric Adams, an Unexpected Influx of Migrants Poses a Major Test
item.description: The mayor has struggled to respond to thousands of migrants arriving on buses, and he has received criticism from every corner.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams has said he still views New York as a sanctuary city, but acknowledges that the influx of homeless migrants has presented unforeseen challenges.

item.title: How New Yorkers Are Stepping In to Help Asylum Seekers
item.description: Volunteers are collecting donations, delivering pizzas and even opening up their homes to help Venezuelan migrants arriving by bus from Texas.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ilze Thielmann, left, Power Malu and Adama Bah, at the Port Authority Bus Terminal where they have spent their mornings assisting newly arrived migrants.

item.title: Sex Discrimination Case in Hawaii Could Change High School Sports Across the U.S.
item.description: It is rare for Title IX cases to go to trial. In Hawaii, a looming case could be a landmark stress test for the 50-year-old law.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen
item.media:credit: Marie Eriel Hobro for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashley Badis played water polo at James Campbell High School, but her team’s season was jeopardized because the school didn’t hire a coach. Her dad stepped in.

item.title: The One Where Matthew Perry Writes an Addiction Memoir
item.description: In “Friends, Lovers and the Big Terrible Thing,” the actor gets serious about sobriety, mortality, colostomy bags and pickleball.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.category: Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing (Book)
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: By the time he was 49, Matthew Perry writes in his new book, he had spent more than half of his life in treatment centers or sober living facilities.

item.title: For New York Governor, The Times Endorses Kathy Hochul
item.description: In-person voting begins on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

item.title: The Way Los Angeles Is Trying to Solve Homelessness Is ‘Absolutely Insane’
item.description: Developing projects should not make a miserable existence for those who’ve devoted their lives to it.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremiah Dean, near an encampment in the parking lot where the Venice Dell Community project may be built in Los Angeles. Mr. Dean is homeless and has been living in a tent in the parking lot for more than three months.

item.title: Let’s Say Gay
item.description: “Queer” has begun to overtake other labels of sexuality. But what does it mean?
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: The Three Blunders of Joe Biden
item.description: How the Biden White House has contributed to the Democratic Party’s midterm troubles.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

item.title: Not-So-Great Britain’s Conservative Crackup
item.description: Was Liz Truss a cat’s paw for a Boris Johnson comeback?
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: David Cliff/Associated Press

item.title: A Town With a Heart, but Few Options, for Migrants
item.description: It’s fruitless to lecture El Paso about the hardship of receiving buses. The government sent it hundreds upon hundreds of people every day.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Stack
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Margelis Polo Negrette, 9, getting a hand from a Customs and Border Protection officer after she and her parents, Marielith Negrette and Eduardo Polo Diaz, crossed the Rio Grande into El Paso in early October, a few days before a policy change that would have barred them from the country.

item.title: Turns Out Sometimes the Government Can Get Things Right
item.description: We pay a lot of attention to government failures. But if we want better outcomes, we must celebrate and learn from the wins, too.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Herd and Donald P. Moynihan
item.media:credit: Pavel Popov

item.title: Where Have All the Cèpes Gone?
item.description: This year, for the first time, I found only a few of these wild mushrooms.
item.dc:creator: Serge Schmemann
item.media:credit: Noah Kalina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mushroom hunts yielded mostly poisonous mushrooms this year, but none of the abundance of cèpes of better times.

item.title: Republicans’ Persistent 2020 Election Doubts
item.description: Hundreds of Republicans running for offices this year have questioned the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Yiyun Li Became a Beacon for Readers in Mourning’
item.description: The novelist Yiyun Li, known for her powerful distillations of personal grief, makes art from subverted expectations.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Kleeman, Jack D’Isidoro, Elisheba Ittoop, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
item.media:credit: Naila Ruechel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yiyun Li at home in Princeton, New Jersey.

item.title: The 2022 Midterms: Is Wisconsin the Future of America?
item.description: In Wisconsin, aggressive and methodical gerrymandering has allowed Republicans to cement their political power. Can Democrats ever make inroads?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: ilbusca/ Getty Images

item.title: Vegetarian Snacks for Diwali and Beyond
item.description: Sweets, extra-crispy samosas, nachos layered with chutney and more recipes.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Hadas Smirnoff.

item.title: Hassles of Cross-Border Trains Hamper EU’s Green Ambitions
item.description: One man is on a mission to find and suggest fixes for all of the flaws making international rail travel in Europe surprisingly hard. Getting more people on trains is key to meeting E.U. climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the railway station in Rumburk, Czech Republic, on the border with Germany. “We need to get more people on trains,” said Jon Worth, the self-appointed monitor of Europe’s railroad system.

item.title: Where Could a Casino Be Built in New York City? What We Know
item.description: Three gambling licenses for downstate New York are up for grabs. Here’s what has been proposed so far, where the casinos might be located and who gets to decide.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Dana Rubinstein
item.category: New York State Gaming Facility Location Board
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Resorts World racino in Queens is one of the leading contenders for a casino license.

item.title: E.V.s Start With a Bigger Carbon Footprint. But That Doesn’t Last.
item.description: The manufacturing and disposal of electric vehicles result in more greenhouse gases than nonelectric models, but that difference will eventually disappear altogether.
item.dc:creator: Eric A. Taub
item.media:credit: Matt Williams
item.media:description: Studies have found that though it’s true that the production of a B.E.V. causes more pollution than a gasoline-powered counterpart, that greenhouse gas emission difference is erased as the vehicle is driven.

item.title: Hurricane Roslyn Hits Mexico as a Category 3 Storm
item.description: The storm brought coastal flooding and dangerous winds to cities along the country’s Pacific Coast, killing at least one person.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hurricane Roslyn flooded streets in Puerto Vallarta, in Mexico’s Jalisco state, on Sunday.

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Break a Phone Addiction
item.description: Whether smartphone overuse constitutes a true addiction is still up for debate, but experts say there are ways to scale down.
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: The Red Adidas Tracksuit Sealed the Deal
item.description: Katherine Bonneau was charmed by Mikhail Kosyan’s ability to be himself, along with his sense of humor and thoughtfulness. They were engaged after seven months.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
